repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Judicial Reform Project,
            Guatemala - Judicial Reform Project, and Colombia - Judicial
            Conflict Resolution Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Judicial Reform Project
            for Ecuador are as follows: outcome was satisfactory; risk
            to the development outcome was modest; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and Borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Judicial Reform Project for
            Guatemala are as follows: outcome was satisfactory; risk to
            the development outcome was negligible; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Judicial Conflict Resolution
            Improvement Project for Colombia are as follows: outcome was
            unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was unsatisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was also unsatisfactory. This Project
            Performance Assessment Report (PPAR) suggests three broad
            lessons. The first is that it is important to adapt the
            objectives and design of the project to local law,
            conditions, and peculiarities. The second lesson highlights
            the need for flexibility in overall approach in the
            conception of the project. In addition, it is essential to
            solicit local knowledge as well as input from specific
            beneficiaries in the process of selecting project
            objectives, design, and implementation arrangements. The
            third lesson is that it is unwise to rely exclusively on
            by-products of case management software to generate the data
            needed for adequate monitoring and evaluation. The key
            recommendation for initiatives in judicial reform is that
            more resources should be invested in identifying local
            experts to give them a leading role in the design,
            execution, and evaluation of projects. This will facilitate
            greater adaptation to the specific conditions of each
            country, and ultimately ensure ownership and sustainability.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            are substantial. Lessons suggest the following. The
            combination of a top-down and bottom-up approach has ensured
            Ecuador's dialogue on the rule of law, expanded to
            non-judicial and non-governmental groups. This participation
            ensured that new areas be placed on the government's
            reform agenda. Most notable, is that the Judiciary has been
            generally receptive to maintaining a dialogue with civil
            society on the rule of law, while the absence of strong
            governmental actors meant the momentum for reform has been
            concentrated within the Judiciary. This perhaps, is unique
            to Ecuador, but by building on small steps, the
            project's objective gradually encouraged the
            judiciary's understanding of, and interest in, the
            reforms. However, while the project concentrated on formal
            justice in Ecuador's most populous cities, the
            Ecuadorian Judiciary should ensure that future reforms be
            implemented throughout the nation's courts, to ensure
            that second class justice does not arise between urban, and
            rural populations. Furthermore, while the project also
            demonstrated the tremendous effort the Judiciary will still
            need to uniformly implement the changes to the criminal
            procedure code, the Bank project has provided the Judiciary
            with concrete experience in implementing major judicial
            reforms, though the country simply does not have the
            capacity to carry out these reforms, and the short-term
            effect of this will be an erosion of public confidence in
            the judiciary--diminishing many gains made during the
            project. Notwithstanding, given that new judicial
            institutions are slow in building credibility; it is in this
            framework that projects should not place undue emphasis on
            their potential leadership.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Providing legal aid for poor
            women in Ecuador

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profiles focuses on the
            Judicial Reform Project  for Ecuador. The project aims at
            increasing efficiency, effectiveness, and transparency in
            judicial process by: 1) improving administration and case
            management procedures and introducing specialized legal
            education programs for judges; 2) improving access to
            justice; 3) expanding the use of alternative dispute
            resolution mechanisms; and 4) providing an adequate judicial infrastructure.
